Well, before I start on, I'll just give a little context and mention that im roughly libertarian.  My gun stance in a nutshell: A gun is like a parachute, when you really need one, nothing else will do.
 
 As a libertarian, I'd still argue for gun ownership even if it turned out that gun ownership resulted in increased crime levels (which it doesnt). This all goes back to individual responsibility and freedom. I want the freedom to be able to defend myself, and I hate the attempt governments make at forming a monopoly on force. The only protection I want from the government is that from foreign powers (of course, a generalization, so dont nitpick me with hypothetical situations...you get my point here). If someone says to me "a gun is designed only to kill and maim", my response would be "and your point is..."?

I never like the argument for gun control over the issue of accidental gun deaths. Everyone knows guns are dangerous. Accidents with dangerous things happen, and that's a risk the owner takes responsibility for when he/she buys a dangerous object. Here is the only place I can feel good drawing a comparison to cars. Cars are large fast moving objects, and as such are dangerous. When you buy a car you take responsibility for your actions using the car, so accidents are your own fault.

 There are some very serious flaws in information portrayed in this article with regards to Australia and I am afraid I would have to suggest that the above website is not a credible source with regards to this particular article. 
 
 At no stage were gun owners "forced" to hand in their weapons. They were given a grace period to register the weapons and ensure their shooters licences were up to date. Many individuals chose to hand in their guns and collect the money, but many others chose to register and keep their weapons. 
 
 Furthermore, it should be clarified that guns have not been banned from the Australian public. Any adult member of the public can still own and operate a registered legal weapon assuming they hold a current shooters licence.
 
 The statistics quoted in Idaho Examiner are highly questionable. I think you would at least need to quote the actual figures, rather than imagined percentages, if you want a more accurate picture. The Australian Institute of Criminology site is certainly a good start as a more unbiased information source, though even it is only basing data on a sample survey.
